docs.lead_paragraph: Ask American consumers whether they support the use of biotechnology in food and agriculture and nearly 70 percent say they do. But ask the question another way, ''Do you approve of genetically engineered (or genetically modified) foods?'' and two-thirds say they do not. Yet there is no difference between them. The techniques involved and the products that result are identical. Rather, the words ''genetic'' and ''engineer'' seem to provoke alarm among millions of consumers.

headline.main: Gene Altered Foods: A Case Against Panic

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column says genetically modified foods, if properly regulated, promise reduction in pesticides, improvement in nutritional value of foods and enhanced agricultural productivity; warns, however, that there are good reasons for concern about powerful technology that is currently imperfectly regulated, including introduction of food allergies and 'escape' of genetically modified genes that could harm other organisms or contaminate other crops; chart describes how genetic modification is performed (M)
docs.snippet: Ask American consumers whether they support the use of biotechnology in food and agriculture and nearly 70 percent say they do. But ask the question another way, ''Do you approve of genetically engineered (or genetically modified) foods?'' and...

docs.lead_paragraph: Stephanie and Mark Bishop can visit their premature daughter in the hospital, talk to her nurses and become fluent in the medical jargon that fills the neonatal intensive care unit, all without leaving home. The Internet-based program that provides these ''virtual visits'' results in greater family satisfaction than traditional care, and may result in babies' being sent home sooner, a study at Boston's Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center suggests.
docs.abstract: Study at Boston's Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center suggests that Internet-based program that provides 'virtual visits' by parents of premature babies to neonatal intensive care unit may result in babies being sent home sooner; study is reported in journal Pediatrics (M)
docs.snippet: Stephanie and Mark Bishop can visit their premature daughter in the hospital, talk to her nurses and become fluent in the medical jargon that fills the neonatal intensive care unit, all without leaving home.    The Internet-based program that...

docs.lead_paragraph: Two cannibals sat beside a large fire, after eating the best meal they'd had in ages. ''Your wife sure makes a good roast,'' commented the first cannibal. Lying in the enclosure of a magnetic resonance imaging machine, the subjects in the experiment had been told not to laugh aloud. Still, brain scans showed that part of the brains' frontal lobes, above the eyes, lighted up as they read the punch line.

headline.main: Using M.R.I., Researchers Explore the Brain in Search of the Funny Bone

docs.abstract: Research led by Dr Dean K Shibata places subjects in magnetic resonance imaging machines to study humor and the brain; scans identify one brain region involved in deciding that something is funny, one generating laughter and one providing happy feelings that accompany laughter; research is presented at Radiological Society of North America conference (M)
